Award.AwardTitle: Evolutionary convergence or parallelism? Examining recurrent patterns of phenotypic evolution in marine scallops
Award.AbstractNarration:
How fast do organisms evolve in nature and what patterns of change are commonly observed? This project addresses both of these fundamental questions using an integrated approach to examine patterns of morphological change in a large group of non-vertebrate taxa (scallops). A primary goal is to use DNA sequence data to reconstruct the relationships among nearly 200 scallop species. Cutting edge, three-dimensional scanning technology will then be used to measure differences in shell shape (which relate to scallop ecology), and the tree of relationships among species will be utilized to retrace the history of morphological diversification in the group. Patterns of repeated evolution (convergence) will be identified, and the rate of morphological evolution will be compared among groups to determine how fast organisms change in different ecological settings.

This project provides considerable educational experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, including research excursions to the Smithsonian Institution, reciprocal training between laboratories with distinct research emphases, and a research-in-education exchange that includes students from a small college and students attending a large research university. The project will employ six persons, including two graduate students, and two undergraduates. Every effort will be made to communicate research findings via articles and public presentations, all of which will include student participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most striking observations in nature is convergence, a similar morphology seen in organisms that are not closely related to one another. It is presumed that convergent morphologies are due similar selective forces in an environment that elicit an equivalent morphological response.  As such, convergence is treated as evidence for adaptation.  It is hypothesized that convergent shell shapes may occur in two or more species of bivalved molluscs, like oysters and clams, if they are found in equivalent habitats and have similar modes of locomotion, attachment or feeding mechanism. The goals of this project were to evaluate the tempo and mode of morphological changes in shell shape across the tree of life for scallops. A molecular phylogenetic tree was generated for the group, and patterns of shell shape variation were evaluated across species that are found in distinct functional groups. The work found that species in different functional groups display differing shell shapes, and that there was morphological convergence in certain groups. The project also developed five new analytical methods to analyze patterns of morphological change in high-dimensional data.

 

As part of the project, the PIs developed a large morphological database containing shell shape from over 1,000 specimens from 123 species. The project also developed a large molecular database of over 672 sequences from 168 species. Both contribute significantly to our scientific knowledge of scallops, and provide the scientific community with important resources. Additionally, a comprehensive software package (geomoph) was developed for the R-programming environment, and has been disseminated to the scientific community so that other researchers interested in evaluating patterns of shape variation in data may perform these analyses.

 

Finally, the project contributed significantly to the development of human resources. Over 20 undergraduate students were trained in molecular phylogenetics or morphometrics, and three graduate students were trained in both disciplines. Three postdoctoral researchers were also trained on the project. Finally, over 30 scientists from eight countries were trained from three morphometrics workshops initiated by the CoPI of the project.
